title: Chat subagent UX
body: Today subagents are run synchronously (the orchestrator agent is blocked until they are complete) and not in parallel (if it starts multiple subagents via parallel tool calls, they are run one at a time). The goal for this month is to run sync subagents in parallel and to have decent UX for this. We can brainstorm about subagents that are spawned in the background and do not block the main agent, but I think it's a much more complex scenario. Run subagents in parallel: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/274630 For a subagent, I would like to see - The name of the custom agent being used (if applicable) - The task description for the subagent (shown today, with a spinner) - Something about what the subagent is currently working on - The final text that the subagent returned (not by default, but on a click or something) And I think I'd like to see this for all subagents currently running in parallel Some things to consider - How are tool confirmations shown for the individual subagent? - Do we need to ensure that the user will always see confirmations in the viewport, even when there are several subagents and a short viewport? - How much of the subagent's history do I see? Just the latest tool or more? - Do we call them subagents, agents (overloaded), something else? - Special handling for edits? The simplest possible thing that comes to mind is something like the thinking blocks we have today. - The title shows the custom agent name (if set, or just 'subagent') and the task description - In the box we only show the current tool. One can click to expand. - We don't show the thinking text, at least for now. - When you expand a finished subagent, you also see the final text returned to the orchestrator. - Confirmations show inside the box Some other things to think about, tying this to other explorations from Joanna - Should we pull confirmations out of the individual subagent box and show them next to the input? For all tool confirmations, not just for subagents? - In this case, need a way to know which subagent the confirmation belongs to, maybe click a button to reveal - Should there be a more structured output for subagents, eg showing the individual edits that came from the subagent? - Can we associate TODOs and subagents, to show the chat response trajectory in a more structured way? - I'm not sure we can really do this today, I think that an agent trajectory is sometimes less linear than its TODOs suggest - But let's keep it in mind if we get TODOs rendering like this - What is the fundamental difference between subagent orchestration and multi-agent orchestration? Is there a world where we render them more similarly? - If we develop better UI for background terminals, think about whether background subagents should be shown in a similar way Also see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-internalbacklog/issues/6539

### Summary
Replace VS Code's Simple Browser with an integrated browser that supports AI-assisted web development workflows. Users can visually select DOM elements, capture screenshots, and export context (HTML, CSS, error logs) directly to AI tools for debugging, modification, and implementation assistance.Context/Background


### Developers frequently need to:
- Inspect live web pages and communicate specific elements to AI assistants
- Debug rendering issues and share visual + code context efficiently
- Iterate on UI changes with AI by providing precise element selection
- Switch between internal preview and external browser testing

Without integrated selection and context export, developers resort to manual copying of HTML, taking separate screenshots, and describing elements verbally‚Äîa slow, error-prone process that breaks flow.

### Description
Build an integrated browser extension for VS Code that maintains all Simple Browser functionality:

Core Capabilities (Simple Browser Parity)
- Launch browser via command palette, editor context menu, and custom UI
- Navigate to any external URL with address bar
- Open current page in external browser (Chrome, Edge, default system browser)
- Element Selection
  - Element Selection Mode: Click to select DOM elements, with visual highlighting
  - Multi-element Selection: Hold modifier key (Ctrl/Cmd) to select multiple elements or maybe it is always continuous with no need to use a key.
  - Context Export: Selected elements export as structured context including may include code and screenshots
  - On hover show element details (default Chrome popover)
- Ability to update settings
- Open browser content in standalone VS Code window (detached view)

New:
- Ability to open more than one browser instance at a time (on Simple Browser, it's limited to a single instance)
- When in its own window have a simple way to send a prompt to the the main prompt area
- Toggle Browser Developer Tools
- Create a setting to choose between the old and new browser experiences, this setting will be used to drive the rollout
- Allow the browser to remember the last URL that was loaded into the browser
- Ability to open links from chat output

Out of scope:
- Select an area of the browser canvas to take a screenshot of
- Testing responsiveness based on predetermined browser sizes
- When an error, have one click ability to send logs as context
- Create a null state for when the integrated browser get launched
- Bookmark URLs to help with forgetting what port things are on

title: Automatically clean up or archive stale copilot chat sessions after Inactivity and task completion in agent mode
body:
<!-- ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Today VSCode cleans up the chat history of GH Copilot every time that it gets restarted, once this happens the user sees a list of the historic sessions in case the user wants to resume the work from one of them.

VSCode might consider a similar approach for sessions that have been inactive for a long period of time, and when using agent mode when their finished without an stop reason.

Why? The user might have already finished the work that was doing and after a period of time might resume the work picking a different task where the current chat history is unrelated to it.

Today as a developer and user of VSCode I have to manually restart the session, making a click to the + icon, two or three times a day. Wondering how many users are missing to do so and they are starting new work by polluting the context with the previous work. 

We might consider on showing a pop up with a clear ask about if the user wants to continue with the current session or wants to start a new one rather than eagerly start a new one. This would still allow users that want to keep using the same session  to do so without having to go through the history chat list

Type: Bug coming from: https://github.com/oxc-project/oxc/pull/17615#discussion_r2669778736 Possible duplicate, but the server is just waiting for `textDocument/formatting`: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/238935 my extension want to use the following code: ```ts // This list is not used as-is for implementation to determine whether formatting processing is possible. const supportedExtensions = [ "json" // ... other extension ]; const clientOptions: LanguageClientOptions = { // Register the server for plain text documents documentSelector: [ { pattern: `**/*.{${supportedExtensions.join(",")}}`, scheme: "file", }, ], ... } ``` I tried with a new `documentSelector` on `clientOptions`. title: VS Code Feature Request: Extension API: Control Tree Item Expansion During Drag Operations
body:
<!-- ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

# VS Code Feature Request: Control Tree Item Expansion During Drag Operations

## Problem

When implementing drag-and-drop in `TreeViews` with hierarchical structures (folders + leaf items), VS Code automatically expands any collapsible tree item when hovering over it during a drag operation. This behavior is hardcoded and cannot be controlled by extensions.

**Real-world scenario**: We're building a connection management tree with folders and connection items. Connections are expandable (they contain databases), but resolving the children requires establishing a real network connection.

During drag-and-drop operations, when a user moves the mouse pointer *over* a connection item to reach a target folder, VS Code forcibly expands the item. **This automatically triggers an unwanted connection attempt**, blocking the UI or causing side effects, even though the user simply wanted to pass over the item.

This behavior makes drag-and-drop functionality essentially unusable for our scenario, as we cannot allow accidental connections during simple UI interactions. It strictly limits the extensibility of `TreeView` for any extension that uses "virtual nodes" -- items that are expandable but aren't simple folders, or require expensive operations to resolve children.

The current behavior assumes that expandable items are **always** valid drop containers, but this isn't true for many hierarchical models where:
- Leaf items can have children for viewing purposes but shouldn't accept drops
- The distinction between "drop onto parent folder" vs "drop into subfolder" matters
- Visual feedback and user intent need to be distinguished

## Impact

This limitation forces us to **disable drag-and-drop entirely** in our scenario to prevent poor user experience and accidental operations.

## Proposed Solution

We need a way to control the hover-expansion behavior programmatically. This could be achieved by:

1.  **A property on `TreeItem`** (e.g., `expandOnDragOver: boolean`) to explicitly opt-out of auto-expansion for specific items.
2.  **A callback in `TreeDragAndDropController`** (e.g., `handleDragOver`) that allows the extension to determine if expansion is allowed for a given target.

Either approach would solve the issue by giving extensions control over when an item should be expanded during user interaction.

---

## Keywords

`TreeView` `TreeDragAndDropController` `drag-and-drop` `dnd` `expansion` `auto-expand` `hover` `handleDrop` `TreeItem` `collapsibleState` `folder` `hierarchy` `drop-target` `extension-api`

title: Support decimal/floating-point values for terminal.integrated.fontSize
body:
<!-- ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The `editor.fontSize` setting supports decimal values (e.g., `11.25`, `13.5`), but `terminal.integrated.fontSize` only accepts whole numbers. Setting a decimal value like `11.25` gets truncated to `11`.

**Current Behavior**

```json
{
  "editor.fontSize": 11.25,
  "terminal.integrated.fontSize": 11.25
}
```
The editor renders at 11.25px, but the terminal gets truncated to 11px.

**Expected Behavior**

`terminal.integrated.fontSize` should support decimal values just like `editor.fontSize`.

**Use Case**

Sometimes the difference between `11` and `12` is too significant. A value like `11.5` would provide better fine-tuning for readability, especially on high-DPI displays.

**Notes**
- The setting schema already defines `type: 'number'` (not `'integer'`)
- xterm.js (the terminal renderer) already supports floating-point font sizes
- This was added for `editor.fontSize` in #10301 (August 2016)

I'd like to work on this. Is this something you'd accept a PR for?

title: Casing transforms in snippets only support Latin characters
body:
Testing #233798

Use the following snippet:
```
"testSnippet": {
  "scope": "javascript,typescript",
  "prefix": "testSnippet",
  "body": "${1} -> ${1/(.*)/${1:/upcase} ${1:/downcase} ${1:/camelcase} ${1:/pascalcase} ${1:/kebabcase} ${1:/snakecase}/}"
}
```

Give it input `oneTwo` you will get ```oneTwo -> ONETWO onetwo oneTwo OneTwo one-two one_two``` which is correct.
Give it input `–æ–¥–∏–Ω–î–≤–∞` you will get ```–æ–¥–∏–Ω–î–≤–∞ -> –û–î–ò–ù–î–í–ê –æ–¥–∏–Ω–¥–≤–∞ –æ–¥–∏–Ω–î–≤–∞ –æ–¥–∏–Ω–î–≤–∞ –æ–¥–∏–Ω–î–≤–∞ –æ–¥–∏–Ω–¥–≤–∞``` which is incorrect as non-Latin letters are not handled correctly (in this case Russian alphabet, but code only cares about a-z).

We should probably use Unicode definition of words if possible to perform the case transforms.

title: Agent sessions: creating new background session is lagging
body:
Originally reported here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/281913

* Creating worktree and the like can be slow, while all of this is happening we don't have a new session in the sessions list

**Slow points**
* Creating worktree
* Possibly even starting a new session (this depends on how fast the CLI is, if we spawn a process in future this could be slower)
* Getting list of sessions and session details for each session could be slow
(we might want to add telemetry for this and cache some of this in memory)
E.g. if user starts a new session, then nothing has changed in the list of session, except to include a new item and return previously returned items

**Solutions**
* List current session in list of sessions and trigger session changed event
* However this has a drawback, `we dont' have a session id`
If we use the new untitled session id and return that in the session list, then this needs to be swapped as well.
I suppose this is fine as thats how the UI works today

**Summary**
* We might as well always list a new session in the sessions list using the `untitled session id`
(except in cases where we have worktree change migration etc, as in those cases we start a new session)

body:
ApplicationInsights proxy support interferes with VS Code's proxy support.

---

Issue: Copilot telemetry is not making its way to GitHub for machines which have an env variable called `http_proxy`, even if that env variable is defined correctly. This is caused by [ApplicationInsights](https://github.com/microsoft/ApplicationInsights-node.js/blob/20fbcb87ff9c361cf5fdfe0e500f857c7c813373/Library/Util.ts#L321) proxy support which interferes with the builtin VS Code's proxy support.

---

Verification:

Run local proxy:
```sh
docker run -d -p 127.0.0.1:3128:3128 --name proxy ubuntu/squid:latest
docker exec proxy tail -F /var/log/squid/access.log
```

Run VS Code with env variables:
```sh
# Bash
http_proxy=http://localhost:3128 https_proxy=http://localhost:3128 code
# PowerShell
$env:http_proxy="http://localhost:3128"; $env:https_proxy="http://localhost:3128"; code; Remove-Item Env:\http_proxy,Env:\https_proxy
```

Verify that the proxy logs for `copilot-telemetry.githubusercontent.com` show status `TCP_TUNNEL` and not `TCP_MISS_ABORTED`.

## üìå Summary

Add a new option in the editor (code canvas) right-click context menu to open the integrated terminal at the currently active file's directory.

## üß© Problem Statement

In VS Code today:

* The editor (main code area) context menu does not provide any way to open a terminal
* Developers must:
  1. Switch to Explorer
  2. Find the file or folder
  3. Right-click ‚Üí Open in Terminal or

## ‚úÖ Proposed Solution

Add a context-menu item when right-clicking inside an open file in the editor:

* Opens the integrated terminal
* Sets the working directory to the parent directory of the currently active file
* If no terminal exists, create one
* If terminal exists, reuse or focus it (consistent with current behavior)

## üîÑ Expected Behavior

1. Open any file in the editor

4. Terminal opens at:

<directory_of_active_file>

* Menu option appears only when a file-backed editor is active
* Hidden for:
  * Untitled editors
  * Read-only virtual documents (unless supported)
* Should respect:
  * Default terminal profile
  * Workspace vs global terminal behavior

## üõ†Ô∏è Implementation Notes (Optional)

* Resolve path via the active editor's `URI`
* Use existing terminal service APIs
* Similar logic already exists for folder-based terminal actions
* Command should be reusable for future extensions

## üåü Why This Feature Is Valuable

* Keeps developers focused in the editor
* Saves multiple clicks per workflow
* Especially useful in monorepos & deeply nested structures
* Aligns with VS Code's productivity-first UX

body:
<!-- ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
## Summary
Add an `Ask` tool that lets an agent ask the user a question mid-workflow and **wait** for the reply as a *pause/resume* operation (not a termination), keeping context and orchestration intact.

## Problem
When an agent needs clarification, the current interaction pattern often turns into a ‚Äústop and ask‚Äù break in execution. This creates a few practical problems:
1. **Workflow continuity breaks**: The system behaves as if the run ended, rather than as a step that is waiting for input. This could become an issue if automatic handoffs or other automation are added.
2. **Less interaction with the user**: To ask for clarifications or simple confirmations, the agent has to stop while it‚Äôs working. That may be discouraged by training, biases, or system prompts, which reduces collaboration with the user.
3. **Context gets muddy**: Stopping for user interaction can clutter the context and lead to duplicated or unnecessary information because of how the chat system works.

## Proposal
Introduce an `Ask` tool with semantics similar to waiting on a sub-agent:
- The agent sends a message/query to the user.
- The run enters a **waiting state**.
- The user receives the message in chat, with some agent-related buttons disabled and a clear indicator that the agent is paused (not stopped).
- When the user responds, the run resumes from the same step, with the reply attached as structured input.

## Benefits
- More agent‚Äìuser interaction, improving output by aligning better with user intent.
- Better safety by letting the agent pause for confirmation before making significant changes.
- A smoother workflow by only pausing when necessary.

## Future opportunities
This tool enables more autonomous workflows where agents involve the user only when needed by requesting missing information or waiting for confirmation before important steps.

`Ask` is the primitive that makes this possible.

title: Surface pinned editor state on hover when navigating files via Explorer
body:
### What this PR does

VS Code clearly indicates pinned files in the editor tab strip, where pinned tabs are visually distinct and ordered predictably. This works well while working within the editor area.

However, when navigating files primarily through the Explorer, the pinned state of a file that is already open in an editor group is not visible at all.

- When a file is pinned in the editor:
- The pinned state is visible only in the editor tab
- The same file, when viewed in the Explorer, appears identical to any other file

There is no way to tell (even on hover) that this file is already pinned and acting as a stable editor tab

This creates a disconnect between the editor and the Explorer, especially when users rely on the sidebar for navigation.

Would it be reasonable to surface the pinned state only on hover in the Explorer, without adding persistent icons or changing layout?

### For example:

On hovering a file in the Explorer that is currently pinned in an editor group
Show a subtle hover indication such as:
A tooltip: ‚ÄúPinned‚Äù
This keeps the Explorer visually unchanged by default while making pinned state discoverable during navigation.

title: Exclude extensions with auto updates disabled from available updates on badge
body:
<!-- ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Short description**
Introduce a setting to suppress including extensions which have updates available **AND** automatic updates disabled from the badge on the _Extensions_ icon in the _Activity Bar_ which shows the number of available updates.

**Full description**
When there are updates available for installed extensions VS Code displays a badge on the _Extensions_ icon in the _Activity Bar_ with the number of extensions with pending updates. Usually this is a helpful visual indicator but it can have the opposite effect for extensions which have had automatic updates disabled. In this scenario, it's common that all extensions are up-to-date except for those that have been deliberately opted-out (i.e. the badge is showing just the number of extensions with automatic updates disabled which have available updates).

This issue is to request the addition of a setting which allows for excluding extensions with automatic updates disabled from the calculation of the number of extensions with pending updates shown as a badge on the _Extensions_ icon. Note this only pertains to the badge; available updates for all extensions, including those with automatic updates disabled, would still be shown as usual when the _Extensions_ pane is focused.

**Rationale**
A common reason for disabling automatic updates for an extension is due to a serious bug in a newer version which would break important functionality. Another still is that broader changes to the workspace are required before the extension can be updated. In these scenarios, the available updates badge only serves as an annoying distraction as the updates can't (or shouldn't) be performed.
